column4: hi people.. i just installed apache2 on my computer to test php files and stuff.. but when i type apache2 in the terminal it gives me the following error: apache2: Syntax error on line 189 of /etc/apache2/apache2.conf: Could not open configuration file /etc/apache2/httpd.conf: No such file or directory
can anyone help me??
you need to type the entire path out: /etc/init.d/apache2
er, sudo /etc/init.d/apache2
are you sure it's not running already?
as i said.. i can't get any output of the status..
it just jumps to the next terminal line
and as I said, are you sure that it's not running already?  use this command:  ps axf | grep apache  or ps axf | grep httpd
11691 pts/1    S+     0:00      \_ grep apache
now i see that there isn't any httpd.conf, but there is a apache2.conf.. i assume that that is the problem.. but i have no idea how to make it look for apache2.conf and not httpd.conf, any ideas?
no, make sure that the correct .conf file exists that it's looking for
and assume nothing.
lol
so what you are suggesting is that i rename the file to httpd.conf?? i just did that.. and nothing happened
what exactly are you typing that makes it stay 'the same'?
sudo /etc/init.d/apache2 start (or restart, stop, status), and then it doesn't give me any output, just jumps to the next line
there's no need to rename anything, you should just make a symbolic link
how do i do that?
thanks, but i know what a terminal is and how i can use it.. but how do i make a symbolic link??
that site will tell you how.
ok thanks i will try it
i don't see anything about it..
